case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Hiralal

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 814 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 814 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 24, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 125 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 24, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 125 of 1958.

facts.text: Hiralal is the respondent and manager of a joint Hindu family carrying on business as Messrs. Tilokchand Kalyanmal.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal, the respondent, is the manager of a joint Hindu family carrying on business in the name and style of Messrs. Tilokchand Kalyanmal.

facts.text: The joint family owns a re-rolling mill situated in Indore City called the Central India Iron and Steel Company.

anchor.surface_text: The joint family owns a re-rolling mill situated in Indore City called the Central India Iron and Steel Company.

facts.text: The family purchases scrap iron locally and imports iron plates from outside.

anchor.surface_text: The said family purchases scrapiron locally and imports iron plates from outside and after companyverting them into bars, flats and plates in the Mills sells them in the market.

facts.text: The family converts scrap iron and imported iron plates into bars, flats and plates in the mills and sells them in the market.

anchor.surface_text: The said family purchases scrapiron locally and imports iron plates from outside and after companyverting them into bars, flats and plates in the Mills sells them in the market.

facts.text: Respondent made default in furnishing returns prescribed by s. 7 of the Act for period April 1, 1954 to March 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent made a default in furnishing the returns prescribed by s. 7 i  of the Act for the period April 1, 1954, to March 31, 1955.

facts.text: On February 27, 1956, Sales-tax Officer Indore determined taxable turnover at Rs. 2,26,000, sales-tax at Rs. 8,000 and imposed penalty of Rs. 1,000 under s. 14(1)(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On February 27, 1956, the Sales- tax. Officer, Indore, determined the taxable turnover at Rs. 2,26,000and the sales-tax payable thereon at Rs. 8,000 and he also imposed a penalty of Rs. 1,000 under s. 14  1   c  of the Act.

facts.text: On February 27, 1956, Sales-tax Officer issued demand notices to respondent for payment of sales-tax and penalty.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day he issued demand numberices to the respondent for the payment of the said sales-tax and the penalty.

facts.text: On September 10, 1956, respondent filed petition in High Court of Madhya Bharat under Articles 226 and 227 of Constitution for writs quashing assessment of tax and penalty and restraining State.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1956, the respondent filed a petition in the High Court of Madhya Bharat  afterwards Madhya Pradesh  under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for the issue of appropriate writs quashing, the assessment of tax and penalty and to restrain the State from giving effect to the said orders of the Sales-tax Officer.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court held iron bars, flats and plates sold by respondent exempted from sales tax under the Notification and quashed orders of Sales-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: A Divi- sion Bench of the High Court held that the iron bars, flats and plates sold by the respondent were exempted from sales- tax under the Notification. In that view, the orders of the Sales-tax Officer were quashed.

facts.text: State filed present appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The state has filed the present appeal, by special leave.

facts.text: Parliament enacted Essential Goods Declaration and Regulation of Tax on Sales or Purchases Act, 1952 (Act No. 52 of 1952) which came into force on August 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Parliament enacted Essential Goods  Declaration and Regulation of Tax on Sales or Purchases  Act, 1952  Act No. 52 of 1952 , which came into force on August 9, 1952.

facts.text: In Schedule I of Essential Goods Act 1952, iron and steel declared essential for the community.

anchor.surface_text: In Schedule I of the said Act, iron and steel were declared essential for the life of the companymunity.

facts.text: Government of Madhya Bharat issued Notification No. 58 dated October 24, 1953 under s. 5 of the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Government of Madhya. Bharat, in exercise of the powers companyferred by S. 5 of the Act, issued the Notification as also Notification No. 59, dated October 24, 1953.

facts.text: Item No. 39 of Schedule I of Notification No. 58: No tax payable on sale of iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: The material part of Schedule I of Notification 58 reads No tax shall be payable on the sale of the following goods No. Description of goods. ---------------------------------------------------------- 39 Iron and steel.

facts.text: Notification No. 59 dated October 24, 1953 describes goods taxable at particular rates, Schedule IV entry 9: goods prepared from any metal other than gold and silver, tax at Rs. 3/2/- per cent on sale by importer or producer.

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 59 described the goods sales of which were taxable at particular rates. Schedule IV thereof reads List of articles under section 5 of the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950, on the assessable sale proceeds of which sales tax at the rate of Rs. 3/2/- per cent. shall be payable... 9 goods prepared from any Sale by imported or pro- metal sale by importer or producer. ducer. other than gold and silver

facts.text: Learned counsel for the State contends that iron and steel means iron and steel in original condition and not iron and steel in shape of bars, flats and plates.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the State companytends that the expression iron and steel means iron and steel in the original companydition -and number iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates.

facts.text: Scrap iron purchased by respondent was merely re-rolled into bars, flats and plates.

anchor.surface_text: Scrap iron purchased by the respondent was merely re-rolled into bars,flats and plates.

facts.text: The raw materials were re-rolled to give attractive and acceptable forms but did not lose character as iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: They were processed for companyvenience of sale.The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did number in the process lose their character as iron and steel.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that bars, flats and plates sold by assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape. We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

facts.text: Conclusion arrived at by High Court is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion arrived at by the High Court is ,correct.

issues.text: whether the said iron bars, flats and plates are not iron and steel within the meaning of Item No. 39 of the Notification

anchor.surface_text: The only question in this appeal is whether the said iron bars, flats and plates are number iron and steel within the meaning of Item No. 39 of the Notification. Parliament enacted Essential Goods  Declaration and Regulation of Tax on Sales or Purchases  Act,

arguments.court_reasoning: In our view, this contention is not sound. A comparison of the said two Notifications brings out the distinction between rawmaterials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latter is taxed.

arguments.claim: A comparison of the said two Notifications brings out the distinction between rawmaterials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latter is taxed.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, this contention is not sound. A comparison of the said two Notifications brings out the distinction between rawmaterials of iron and steel and the goods prepared from iron and steel while the former is exempted from tax, the latter is taxed.

arguments.claim: Iron and steel used as raw-material for manufacturing other goods are exempted from taxation. So long as iron and steel continue to be raw-materials, they enjoy the exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Scrap iron purchased by the respondent was merely re-rolled into bars,flats and plates. Therefore, iron and steel used as raw-material for manufacturing other goods are exempted from taxation.

arguments.claim: The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did not in the process lose their character as iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: They were processed for convenience of sale.The raw-materials were only re-rolled to give them attractive and acceptable forms. They did not in the process lose their character as iron and steel.

arguments.claim: The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape. Therefore, the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape. We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer sold iron and steel in the shape of bars, flats and plates and the customer purchased iron and steel in that shape. We, therefore, hold that the bars, flats and plates sold by the assessee are iron and steel exempted under the Notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-rolling scrap iron and imported plates into bars, flats, and plates does not change their essential character as iron and steel; they are processed for sale convenience, remain raw materials entitled to exemption, distinguished from goods prepared from iron and steel under Notification 59 via harmonious construction; sold and purchased as iron and steel.

holdings.text: The conclusion arrived at by the High Court is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion arrived at by the High Court is ,correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly interpreted Item No. 39 of Notification No. 58 to exempt the respondent's sales of re-rolled iron bars, flats, and plates as iron and steel.
